sections.title: Client: Adobe Software
sections.description: I was hired to help a customer services team strategize around a project to improve methods of collecting user feedback, ala re-design feedback forms in various areas of Creative Cloud offering (Creative Cloud sign-up, installation, and applications).  The overall goal of the initiative was to make customer and user feedback contextually relevant to their place within the ecosystem (i.e. in an app or on adobe.com)

sections.title: The Starting Point
sections.description: I worked collaboratively with the stakeholders to comprehend primary and secondary goals for customers as well as internal team member users, so management roles might also interact with the feedback model to inform product updates and new product roll-outs.  The idea was to pair feedback with analytics for a complete Voice of the Customer representation.  I was given free-range to explore directions outside the standard feedback collection form and forum posts (Adobe’s current method for collecting user feedback).

sections.title: Research & Analysis
sections.description: After researching, experiencing and documenting  Adobe’s existing feedback collection models, as well as other industry models.  I then developed 2 target user profiles, (a non-creative pro novice, as well as a creative pro expert) both who might be new to Creative Cloud model and ecosystem.  I also researched multiple external industry sites and how they collected feedback.  I did multiple cognitive walk-throughs with participants to observe top-level issues, frustrations and pain points and how they might currently share their feedback.

sections.title: More Research & Analysis
sections.description: I also conducted research throughout the initiative that included a deep dive into current artificial intelligence industry trends and leading company products. I reviewed applications that featured chatbots, virtual assistants and machine learning. I then  captured highlights about their features with screenshots and annotations regarding functionality and technology. I collected articles from a number of market research companies such as Forrester and Gartner and included quotations and industry insights focused on machine learning and self-assisted help as well as general projections about the field of AI.  I integrated all the research into a final report and delivered it with the final prototype.

sections.title: UX / UI / IA Design
sections.description:
In this phase, I designed and presented a round of concepts that demonstrated how a user might interact with a assisted self-help application (similar to a chatbot), along with additional features that included archiving, gamefication, and the ability to integrate social gestures.

Initially, I named the bot "Shout", thinking that it would be an inviting name that would entice users to speak their minds and share feedback, i.e. "shout out" to Adobe to share rants, raves, ideas and ask questions while using a desktop application or viewing content on their site. "Shout" was presented to many teams within Adobe and revised 3 times. The basic model remained, but the branding moved to “Adobe Bot” and finally to "Leo". The brand design for "Leo", as well as the look-n-feel, voice and model for interaction was simulated in a final click-through prototype. The format was a conversational script that allowed us to gather feedback from participants who aligned with our target personas.

sections.title: User Feedback & Reporting
sections.description:
The concepts for "Leo" were transitioned into a click-through prototype design (as shown above), and designed to demonstrate the user experience. I wrote the introduction, instructional and conversational copy to simulate interaction with Leo. The sequencing followed scenarios for both novice and expert user profiles. I also wrote scripts for each one that simulated how each of the roles might interact with the application, following cases of initial discovery to in-app interaction and other areas of the app (archiving, points, account settings).

Since gathering feedback was the initial base for this project, I made sure to include designs that would demonstrate various ways that the application could collect user feedback.

Screener and participant recruiting was completed collaboratively with stakeholders. I conducted the one-on-one feedback sessions with 14 participants in an hour-long session each. After the sessions, I wrote a report that included the feedback with highlighted quotes and recommendations for all the areas of the prototype.
